thread.title: Giant panda cubs born at Toronto Zoo
thread.title_full: Giant panda cubs born at Toronto Zoo | Toronto Star

title: Giant panda cubs born at Toronto Zoo
text:
In a Canadian first, two giant panda cubs were born at the Toronto Zoo this morning.
Er Shun, a female giant panda on loan from China, gave birth to the first cub at 3:31 a.m. The second cub was born at 3:44 a.m.
“We are so proud to be contributing to the ongoing survival of this endangered species,” zoo CEO John Tracogna said in a news release.
The cubs weighed 187.7 grams and 115 grams. Giant panda cubs are about the size of a stick of butter at birth, the zoo says, and are pink with short, sparse white hair.
Er Shun demonstrated “excellent maternal instincts” as she cleaned and cradled the first cub soon after it was born, the zoo said. The animals’ handlers do not yet know the cubs’ sex, and it may take several months before that can be confirmed.
Due to their small size, the next days are crucial to the panda cubs’ survival. They will be held in the maternity area of the zoo’s panda house for several months.
The zoo announced Er Shun was pregnant with twins on Sept. 30 after she was artificially inseminated last May.
The giant pandas are on loan at the Toronto Zoo until 2018, at which point they will be moved to the Calgary Zoo.
